title: Identification of Plastic Materials in Museum Collections with Infrared Spectroscopy

author: Andreja Padovnik, Zavod za varstvo kulturne dediščine Slovenije (ZVKDS)

segmentation: Today I will present to the presentation with address identification of plastic material in museum collections with infrared spectroscopy like you see from the address.
In our project we analyze plastic material with infrared spectroscopy and maybe just for introduction.
Then Spila and Nicholas show me all these plastic objects and told me what they expect from us.
My first thought was why we have to do this and what was the meaning of this?
And because these are just plastic objects and don't have any value and now I know that I was wrong.
So yes.
For the beginning, the Institute I'm coming from the Institute for the Protection of Cultural Heritage of Slovenia.
This is a public Institute that carries out professional and administrative tasks with regards to the preservation of immovable and corresponding Marvel properties and intangible cultural heritage.
This Institute is divided into section culture, here to service Anna Conservation Center and.
And you can see also that conservation centers is divided into 3 parts and I'm coming from the restoration center and and work in the Department for Natural Science Research this.
This Department carries out preliminary science analyze on the historical objects so.

The project where I work on the plastic material.
And it was everything new for me, so I have to start in the beginning.

What is a plastic so uh, plastic is a polymer polymer based material which can be modified with different additives and then shape to the stable form.
So we knew three groups of plastics.
I mean polymers first is natural polymers which can be.
Before metal by blends trees, insects and then we have semi synthetic plastics.
This was developed after 1839.
And this semi synthetic plastics are natural polymers which which are modified with chemistry.
And then we have a synthetic plastics which was developed after 19 seven.
Not until now we knew around 50 different groups of synthetic plastic.
This is basic groups, but then but with edit is we have around 60,000 plastic formulation an and this is one of the reasons why.

Because composition and based on the composition and degradation we can develop appropriate conservation strategy and this can help us for selection of proper condition.
Conditions for storage and also proper restoration treatment we have to.
But another thing that degradation process also affected on physical and chemical properties, and because of these can be identification also difficult.
For intensification, we have a few techniques.
First, this is simply non destructive identification techniques.

Is.
